item.description:
It is such a beautiful evening so I am heading out for a hike to Soapstone Hill overlooking the Quabbin reservoir and would love company if anyone wants to join me. There is limited parking at the Women's Federated Forest so I have limited this hike to 5. Also the road in is quite long and not in great shape. I get through it just fine in my Monte Carlo though.

This hike takes approximately 1 1/2 hours and is mostly easy terrain with a small ascend to Soapstone Hill. We should back in plenty of time before dark but please bring your headlamp or flashlight just in case.

Federated Women's Club State Forest

New Salem Rd. (Rte. 122), Petersham, MA
(978) 939-8962

Numerous trails, one to an overlook of Quabbin Reservoir, plus primitive camping (see camping section).

Description:

With over 1,000 acres, this forest extends the lands that protect the Quabbin Reservoir; tent campers can stay here (with a permit from Dennison Lake Recreation Area, 978-939-8962) as they explore the reservoir. The camping area, in fact, lies very near Gate 36, the trail through which leads directly to the shore. There’s much to explore in the state forest as well, however - a very scenic drive or hike on State Forest Rd. along Fever Brook and other, unmarked trails to the boulder-strewn Gorge and to the summit of Soapstone Hill, with a wonderful view of the Quabbin. As its name implies, this land was purchased by the Massachusetts State Federation of Women’s Club and then given to the Commonwealth.

Directions:

From Petersham Center go south on South Main St. 0.4 mi., turn right on New Salem Road (Rte. 122) 3.6 mi. to entrance on left

Click for a Map

The Massachusetts Federation of Women's Club State Forest lies in Petersham and New Salem on Route 122. Its 984 acres stretch to the south and west in the watershed of the Quabbin Reservoir. Please Note that NO pets are allowed on DCR Watershed Property. Groves of pine and stands of maple, birch and hemlock invite the visitor along the wooded roads. The road along Fever Brook is outstanding for its scenery. A wildlife sanctuary compromising 140 acres has been set aside in the center of the forest, and a dam on Fever Brook holds back sufficient water to attract migrating and native wild fowl. In the southwest section is the forest's chief geological feature, the Gorge.
